Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 08:36PM - edited Feb 4, 2009 08:39PM by VickiG Oh, and for a little more input on auto transplants, it has been noted here on the board that it seems like long-term survivor stories seem to have AUTO transplants in common.  I believe the reason for that is because 15 yrs ago it was much more common to get them, so it's more likely that someone who was tx'd 15 yrs ago had a transplant than someone just 5 yrs out.  Also, some women respond very well to chemo, some do not.  Since the transplants were giving massive amts of chemo, those same women who did well might have done just as well w/ "regular" tx instead, and those who did not do well w/ conventional tx might not have done any better w/ massive chemo.  The reason ALLO is appealing to me is that it is NOT relying on chemo, it is trying to replace my faulty immune system w/ a healthy one that might fight the cancer for me.  I really hope this helps clear up some questions... please feel free to ask me more about it & I'll try to share what I can.
Posts.Title: Stem Cells Rene2000 Maryiz

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 08:31PM - edited Feb 4, 2009 08:37PM by VickiG OK, I'll jump in here since I was scheduled to have an allogeneic (donor) stem cell transplant last month, but the protocol was cancelled just before Christmas.  This trial was to be at the Natl Cancer Inst in Bethesda, MD.  This is the same trial that our own JillT took part in.  The big difference between allo & auto is what they are trying to achieve ~ like FlaLady has written above, AUTO transplants are simply a means of blasting patients w/ massive amts of chemo, so their stem cells need to be protected during this tx.  ALLO, however, does use chemo, but just for low-dose conditioning to get your immune system ready to accept donor cells.  Rather than using chemo as the weapon, the idea is that the donor cells will fight the tumor itself.  The theory is that the Graft vs. Host Disease common to transplants could actually have a similar effect on the tumor; that is, Graft vs. Tumor effect where the donor cells attack the tumor.  This is a successful tx for blood-born cancers but they are trying to figure out how to make it work for solid tumors.  This trial tweaks the donor T-cells to train them to have GVT w/ minimal GVHD if that makes sense... I'm picturing little cells w/ tiny whips & chairs like lion tamers.  Part of the reason I was very optimistic about this trial personally is because I have extensive skin mets, and since skin is a major GVHD complication, the thought was that I would be going into this w/ significantly improved odds of response... I do realize that it has yet to work for us, but someday it WILL, and I am not opposed to being the first success story with it.  I hope that sort of explains things ~ believe me, I have gathered a LOT of info on this lol.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 09:17AM VickiG wrote: I have been a SAHM since giving birth to our oldest, now 13 (the others are 11, 9, and 7.)  Our plan was for me to go back to work (not necessarily the same job, but to do something) once they were all in school.  I was dx'd 2 mos before our youngest started K, we decided work was staying on the back burner for a while.  After I finished tx (ha!) last spring I decided it was time to go back... found the perfect thing, working p/t at the library just a mile from our house.  Before I could even get the app filled out I found out I had mets... shit!  I still thought going back was a possibility but I keep having progression, so it seems like the only work I have time to do is to work on trying to stay well!  I do embroidery, so I am thinking I really should work on turning it into more of a biz than a hobby.  I'm having so much fatigue now that I seriously wonder just how realistic working would be.  I do LOVE being a SAHM by the way... best thing in the world I have ever done and do not regret a single minute of it.

Posts.Content: VickiG wrote: I don't know if I've just become sensitive lately, but a couple of friends have said things that REALLY bothered me... talked to dh about it & he completely agreed, so maybe it isn't just me?  But I have noticed that there are certain things that other people just do not have the "right" to say to us, and I wonder how it is some people actually say the dumb things that come out of their mouths.  Two different things are sticking in my mind right now, so I'm going to vent if that's ok: 1)  This is from a casual friend ~ she is also friends w/ my best friend, so she does know pretty much what is going on, but *I* do not share stuff w/ her.  I was picking my son up from her house the other day & she started lecturing me on journaling for the kids, that I HAVE to do that & it will be impt for when they are adults.  OK, yes it's true, and I do have journals ready to go for all of them, dh, my parents, brothers, etc.... but I just am not ready to do it.  I was a little offended that she felt she needed to explain to me what my family needs from me, what I need to do to get ready to leave them. 2)  A friend was concerned that I've dropped off the face of the earth lately ~ I hadn't told anybody about my brain mets, still trying to deal w/ that one.  So I decided to go ahead & share what's going on... she wrote back "hopefully the new chemo will blast the nasty mets to hell LOL."  WTF?!  OK, maybe I'm just looking for fault, but who says things like freaking LOL in the same sentence as that?  This is when I decided that the decadron must be affecting my emotions, so I actually talked to dh about it... he's my voice of reason, the one to always assume the best, not the worst, from others, etc.  And he was pissed ~ so maybe it's not just me?  Do others not have the right to get to LOL about our issues, or am I being a whiney baby? Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 06:38AM VickiG wrote: Hi Oz!  I just started on Abraxane last week... my treatment is once every 3 wks.  My onc no longer talks about how many txs or how long I'll be on anything... when I first was dx'd stage 4 she put me on Taxol for "11 or 12 mos" but I only lasted 3 before having progression & needing to change chemos... now I think I'm on #12 so she definitely does not bother telling me how many txs I'll get, we just assume I'll be on it until the next progression.  Anyway, I think it's exciting that your onc would even use words like "bring you into remission" ~ I'm certainly hoping that's what happens to me while I'm on it!!!  I have to say that I had some major tumor pain the couple of days following my infusion... my skin mets felt like I had hundreds of needles poking into them & my enlarged lymph nodes absolutely throbbed... so I am convinced that this chemo is actually attacking the tumors.  A chemo buddy of mine was on Abraxane & it did bring her into remission... so I'm hoping for the same for everyone else who is on it!

Posts.Content: VickiG wrote: Yesterday when I went for chemo I mentioned to my onc that I've had dizziness lately ~ not that I necessarily was concerned that it's related to my brain mets, but just wanted to mention it since it's a new thing I've noticed.  She wanted me to have a head CT after chemo ~ I didn't think it was urgent, but went ahead & had it.  Wasn't expecting results until today, but she called later yest afternoon to say that the largest lesion has shrunk, and the two smaller ones are GONE.  There are 2 more small ones that were not on the initial scan so she was concerned, but those had shown up on the MRI the morning of Gamma Knife so all 5 were treated that day (no idea why my onc was not informed of that, though!)  And there is no more edema, so the evil decadron at least did its job ~ guess I can stop complaining about all the horrid SEs lol.  Anyway, I never seem to get good scan news, so this was very exciting, woohoo!  I'll have the rest of my scans done in 3 wks, and hopefully those will be as good.  =) Vicki Dx 6/9/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 10/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2008 08:42AM VickiG wrote: I just had one 2 days ago so the "instructions" are still fresh in my little mind ha ha.  For morning appts, no food after midnight, but for my afternoon appt I was allowed eat a light bkfst before 8 & clear liquids at noon ~ I had a cup of broth.  Drink 1st bottle of contrast 1 hr before appt, the 2nd one 30 min. before.  Tell her to drink PLENTY of water the days of & after the CT to help flush everything out of her system ~ the contrast is rough on the kidneys.  The tech will explain everything to her as they are getting her ready for it so she knows just what to expect. Good luck to your mom!!!!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 09:02AM VickiG wrote: We Relay, but it is more for my kids than any other reason ~ it means a lot to them to be part of something that is so much bigger than we are, and to see that we are not alone.  Also it is not a bc thing, it's ALL cancer, and that seems to make a difference, no pink crap.  We Relayed Fri night & I have to admit it was much harder this yr than it was last yr ~ last yr I had just been dx'd Stage IV, but I really didn't accept the dx because it was "just" my internal mamm nodes, barely on the other side, so how can that be "distant"?  It wasn't till July when it went to my skin that reality hit me.  Anyway, it was MUCH harder this yr, but I also saw how many people are there to support my family, and that was a wonderful feeling.  Some of the kids' teachers were there to walk w/ us, friends, etc... and I realized that even if I'm not there next yr, all of them would still be right there w/ my family, both for Relay and for every day.  The thing that's hard for me is to listen to the inspirational success stories ~ "I have beaten cancer twice in the past 8 years so you will be fine, too..."  Wouldn't that be nice.  One thing that WAS very nice to hear was when one of the oncs from my clinic spoke ~ he's a survivor himself, self-dx'd his lymphoma when he was in college.  Anyway, everybody who spoke said why they relay, and he said it's for all of their patients... maybe that's not such a big thing, but it meant a lot to hear that all of them were there for US, not the standard "for hope" blah blah blah.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 07:26AM VickiG wrote: LuAnn ~ thanks for your dose of sensibility... you're right.  And I do trust my onc or I would not be with her... it's just hard to pace myself w/ this, know what I mean?  I want it to be gone, so it's hard to wait to see if the strategy is the right one.  And she did tell me that she always prefers to do single drugs when possible rather than throwing out a new combo since then you never know what's working or not.  I guess when it first came up tho was when I was on Taxol for chest wall mets & then it went to my skin ~ she took me off Taxol & we went to Ixempra/Xeloda.  Mayo & Emory both thought instead we should have just added Avastin to the Taxol since even tho it went to my skin it seemed like the Taxol was working on my chest.  Unfortunately for all of us, there simply is no rule book for this disease ~ wouldn't that make things easier!!!!  Thanks again LuAnn ~ think I needed a little refocus.  =)

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 07:06PM VickiG wrote: Met w/ my onc before chemo today and she asked what I think about adding Avastin to my Navelbine.  She said she's struggled w/ giving me 2 new things since it's good to use just 1 if that's enough, but it's also hard to NOT give something that might work well... so what we are tentatively going to do is complete this cycle w/ just Navelbine, and then for the next cycle add Avastin.  I swear in the past wk something is happening, though ~ my pelvic lymph node is definitely a little smaller, and my skin mets are fading a little.  Could it be the Navelbine this soon after just one tx?  Could it be lingering Ixempra/Xeloda mixing in w/ the Navelbine?  Could it be the Aldara cream that's working on the skin?  Could it be the mental health boost I got from a wknd w/ the family at Sea World & Busch Gardens ~ in particular surviving a loopy roller coaster even after the carousel made me want to hurl???  I have no idea... maybe my body just needed something positive to happen this week for a change?

Posts.Content: VickiG wrote: I have a nasty case of thrush... any advice on what will help?  I'm on Diflucan but only was rx'd 5 days of that & somehow I do not think that's going to do the trick since I've already had 3 and am in as much throat/esophagus pain now as I was before starting, plus the mouth sores are not improving.  I can barely eat OR drink ~ in fact, I just realized that I've been sitting here w/ a mouth full of coffee because I'm afraid to swallow.  What I have found is that warm things are easier to drink, that anything cold is REALLY painful (so much for the idea of popsicles.)  I know I am not drinking enough now because it's so hard to make myself do it.  Oh, and what caused it?  Yet another SE of the evil Decadron, big surprise, hm?  It actually started several wks ago, when the other SEs started popping up, but we did not realize what it was until it really started kicking my butt last wk.  Any suggestions about how to get some relief or what to eat/drink would be much appreciated!  Thanks so much, Vicki Dx 6/9/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 10/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 11:47PM VickiG wrote: I feel very fortunate that my center is as great as it is ~ it really upsets me to hear about others' bad experiences in theirs.  Our nurses are very protective of us lifers... they somehow manage to run interference when newbies who know everything show up & start telling us how to cope.  I usually have the same nurse, but have had pretty much everybody take care of me at some point & have never had a bad experience w/ anyone.... which I think says so much about the practice.  They call it the "chemo lounge" and I guess that's a good name for it... it's a large "T" shaped room that has windows all the way around, even two patios we can wheel out to if we want.  They recently added tvs & I hate those... it's almost always the visitors watching anyway.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 01:09PM VickiG wrote: Thank you so much everyone for all of the great ideas, I really appreciate them all!  I also dragged my butt over to talk to the pharmacist & he also recommended Magic Mouthwash.... and said that oncologists rx it all the time because of chemo & rads.... sigh.  Would have been nice if mine had done that.  He said in the meantime to gargle w/ Benadryl/Maalox, which is Magic Mouthwash w/o the Lidocaine.  One thing I'm wondering, though, is that since I'm not swallowing it, seems like it will only help my mouth, yet my entire esophagus hurts when I swallow anything?  Actually, the sores I have in my mouth are nothing compared to the pain in my throat.  Hm, I guess swallowing the Benadryl/Maalox isn't actually a pbly since those are both things to swallow anyway... and my allergies might be more cooperative, ah, the silver lining that has been eluding me all this time.  I freaking hate this disease.

Posts.Content: VickiG wrote: Last night was the Survivor Dinner/Fashion Show.  10 of us are featured in our breast health center's "Portraits of Life" calendar so we all were invited to be the "models".  It was very nice ~ I have become close to several of the other ladies since we did the photos back in July.  One of the ladies back in July told me that I should get my boobs done since that would make me feel better about my dx (that was the wk I was dx'd w/ skin mets, a very rough wk for me, and I wanted to hit her for saying that boobs would make everything all better for me.)  Anyway, fast fwd to last night ~ same bimbo came up to me to see how my tx is going etc... she said "You're lucky that yours came back so soon so you never had a chance for your hair to grow out before losing it again.  It would be much harder for me to lose mine now that it's taken so long for me to have long hair again."  I was shocked!!!!  I told her I don't know about that, that my clock started ticking back in March when I first was dx'd w/ mets, so it would have been nice if I'd gotten a few extra yrs, too!  And she actually works for the ACS!!!!! Vicki Dx 6/9/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 10/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Survivor Dinner VickiG Fllorik

Posts.Content: VickiG wrote: In the past year I have definitely become less fit... chemo is NOT a girl's best friend!  I've never been one to "exercise" ~ I've always been in fairly good shape, but I attribute that mostly to my chasing-after-four-kids exercise plan lol.  I decided that our family needed a Wii, just so I could get a Wii Fit.  Wow, this has been so great for me!  I've never been one to go to a gym, but I am willing to fire up the Wii in the mornings... I can actually feel my muscles getting toned, woohoo!  I wish I'd had this after my mast since it's really helping me get back some of the flexibility I've lost since surgery ~ the yoga & strength exercises have been a big help to me.  It's been good mental therapy for me, too ~ starts my day off w/ a great attitude, which is nice since I seem to hit the wall of fatigue every afternoon.  Does anyone else have one?  I am so glad we got it, only wish I'd thought of it sooner.  The kids love it, too ~ and I have a lot of fun watching them play their games on it, too... it has given dh & me much, much laughter, which is a wonderful thing ANY day. Vicki Dx 6/9/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 10/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 08:47AM VickiG wrote: The "survivor" thing gets me, too.  You can survive a car wreck or a house fire or a lightning strike or a bad haircut, but once you're done with those things they don't get another shot at you.  When I was going through tx for my initial dx I had no idea when survivorship begins, so when I would hear 1-, 5-, 20-, etc. yr survivor I didn't know when those clocks started. It wasn't until I was done w/ tx (ha!  little did I know how wrong I was about being finished!) that I found out that survivorship starts at the time of dx.  My mom felt that didn't make sense, that it should be starting w/ when tx is finished.  I pointed out that all of us are survivors, so that did she consider those who do not get tx not survivors?  Once I started back in tx just 2.5 mos later, we REALLY realized how dumb it was to think that it starts when you are finished tx.  Well, maybe I was a "survivor" for those 2.5 mos, and then moved into "surviving" status.  I love the SURVIVING ~ I think it says it all.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 01:54PM VickiG wrote: You scared me Stephanie ~ when I saw "I'm Done" I was horrified to think you were giving up the fight.  What a relief to realize that is NOT what you meant!!!!!!  That being said, don't you dare leave ~ we need you... I need you to be here.  You were one of the very first women here whose words really touched me, who made me realize that even though all of this sucks for us, we are very much in it together.  I am assuming the stupid PM was pbly in reference to brownies since the last time you mentioned the subject you were assaulted, too.  It just ticks me off that anybody here would even consider being judgmental!!!!  Perhaps we are all unique women and might not even share much in common other than this disease, but we should all have compassion, empathy, love, and respect, no matter what our personal beliefs about anything else.  We love you and we need you, and anybody who has a problem with that has much bigger problems in life than breast cancer!!!!!!!!!  So there!  (Wow, that felt good to get off my chest...)

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 09:55AM VickiG wrote: I am so sorry about your progression... hopefully rads & your new chemo will kick that @#$%^ cancer in the @$$.  Thank you for sharing ~ it makes me crazy when they say things like "oh that never happens."  I think that's bs ~ this disease is so sneaky and unpredictable that I really do not think any responsible doc should tell patients that something NEVER happens.  I have questioned why my "whole body PETs" have been neck to pelvis (head once, and only because I complained of dizziness).  They said "chest/abd/pelvis is considered whole body because mets would not go to the extremities."  Again, bs.  I'm so tired of my onc telling me how unusual everything is about me, too ~ there seem to be a LOT of us out there who are "unusual" so they should start paying attn more to things they seem to think "never" happen.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 10:08AM VickiG wrote: My kids (7, 9, 11, 13) do understand the reality we're facing, but my oldest simply does not accept that I can lose this fight, so I tend to jump right on board w/ him on that one.  After all, if he refuses to accept that I could possibly die, why in the world shouldn't I believe him?  He's brilliant, so he pbly knows something we don't ~ I'm going w/ that!    My youngest wrote to Santa asking for me to survive from bc... so of course she has to get that wish because Santa always comes through.  I do believe that our kids give us a strength that nobody else could possibly believe or understand.  I met w/ my bs the other day (yet another bx... but hey, it was a good excuse to have a chat!) and she told me how she has always admired me for how I have handled this.  She cut me off before I could give her the "oh puhlease, not the speech" and said that regardless of how I might minimize my awesomeness (I'm paraphrasing lol), that she sees a wide array of women going thru this & what she sees is my unwavering devotion to my family.  But that's what she does not understand ~ I am not the strong one; it's my family that gives me the strength.  Perhaps I'm living in d'Nile (what a lovely place to be!) but it really is a beautiful place to live!  On my facebook page I have had "Make every day the best day of your life" and "There is no good excuse to have a bad day" as my little quote thing... after yet another bad bx I have updated it to "Put on your big girl panties and make every day the best day of your life.  Seriously!"
